<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
</script>

<meta name="post_tags" content="babuk,BlueSky Ransomware,conti ransomware,Grumpy Scorpius,Investigation and Response,Powershell,Redline infostealer,threat intelligence,Zealous Scorpius"/>
<meta property="og:post_image" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/Unit42-blog-2by1-characters-r4d1-2020_Ransomware-v1.png"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"BlueSky Ransomware: Fast Encryption via Multithreading","name":"BlueSky Ransomware: Fast Encryption via Multithreading","description":"BlueSky ransomware is an emerging family that has adopted modern techniques to evade security defenses. Read our technical analysis.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/bluesky-ransomware\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/bluesky-ransomware\/","datePublished":"August 10, 2022","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nBlueSky ransomware is an emerging family that has adopted modern techniques to evade security defenses.\r\n\r\nRansomware is a malicious program designed to encrypt a user\u2019s data and demand a ransom for the decryption. BlueSky ransomware predominantly targets Windows hosts and utilizes multithreading to encrypt files on the host for faster encryption.\r\n\r\nIn our analysis, we found code fingerprints from samples of BlueSky ransomware that can be connected to the Conti ransomware group. In particular, the multithreaded architecture of BlueSky bears code similarities with Conti v3, and the network search module is an exact replica of it.\r\n\r\nHowever, in another respect, BlueSky more closely resembles Babuk Ransomware. Both use ChaCha20, an algorithm for file encryption, along with Curve25519 for key generation.\r\n\r\nAccording to research done by CloudSEK, PowerShell scripting is used to drop and download BlueSky ransomware from a fake website to encrypt data. After successful encryption, BlueSky Ransomware renames the encrypted files with the file extension .bluesky and drops a ransom note file named # DECRYPT FILES BLUESKY #.txt and # DECRYPT FILES BLUESKY #.html.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers receive protections from BlueSky ransomware and other types of ransomware through Cortex XDR, the Next-Generation Firewall and cloud-delivered security services including WildFire. The Advanced URL Filtering subscription provides real-time URL analysis and malware prevention for BlueSky ransomware.\r\n\r\nIf you think you may have been impacted by a cyber incident, the Unit 42 Incident Response team is available 24\/7\/365. You can also take preventative steps by requesting any of our cyber risk management services.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nRansomware, Conti Ransomware\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nInitial Dropper\r\nAs shown in Figure 1, BlueSky ransomware is initially dropped by the PowerShell script start.ps1, which is hosted at hxxps:\/\/kmsauto[.]us\/someone\/start.ps1. The initial dropper is Base64-encoded and then DEFLATE-compressed, which is common behavior observed among PowerShell droppers.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_124422\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 1. Initial dropper.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAfter extracting the embedded Base64-encoded stream from start.ps1, the decoded and uncompressed data stream led to yet another PowerShell script called stage.ps1. This script contained countless irrelevant comments in an attempt to conceal malicious activity. After removing these excessive comments, we discovered that start.ps1 downloaded a number of payloads from hxxps:\/\/kmsauto[.]us\/someone\/ based on the user\u2019s privileges, as shown in Figure 2.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_124424\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 2. Initial dropper (decoded).[\/caption]\r\nLocal Privilege Escalation\r\nBefore downloading additional payloads to perform local privilege escalation, the PowerShell script, stage.ps1, determines if it is being executed as a privileged user. If so, it moves to the next step and downloads and executes the ransomware payload. If not, it uses the following techniques to escalate local privileges, depending on the version of the host operating system. If the version of the host operating system is earlier than Windows 10, such as Windows 7, 8 or XP, then the script will download and execute a modified version of the local privilege escalation tool called JuicyPotato. If the host is running Windows 10 or later, then the script will download and execute ghost.exe and spooler.exe to exploit local privilege escalation vulnerabilities CVE-2020-0796 and CVE-2021-1732 respectively.\r\nRansomware Payload\r\nAfter gaining additional privileges, stage.ps1 downloads the final BlueSky ransomware payload from hxxps:\/\/kmsauto[.]us\/someone\/l.exe and saves it locally to the filesystem as javaw.exe, attempting to masquerade as a legitimate Windows application. Eventually, the sample executes from the file path %APPDATA%\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Start Menu\\Programs\\Startup\\javaw.exe.\r\nRansom Note\r\nBlueSky drops the ransom note as a text file named # DECRYPT FILES BLUESKY #.txt and an HTML file named # DECRYPT FILES BLUESKY #.html in a local directory where it has encrypted files successfully and renamed them with the file extension .bluesky. The content of # DECRYPT FILES BLUESKY #.html is shown in Figure 3.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_124426\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 3. BlueSky ransom note.[\/caption]\r\nAnti-Analysis Techniques\r\nBlueSky implements multiple anti-analysis techniques, including string encryption, API obfuscation and anti-debugging mechanisms, allowing it to obfuscate Windows API function names and use indirect calls for resolving APIs. Additionally, BlueSky encodes API names using DJB hashing functions as shown in Figure 4, hindering malware analysis.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_124428\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 4. DJB hash matching.[\/caption]\r\nRansomware Artifacts\r\nBlueSky generates a unique user ID by computing the MD5 hash over the combined Volume Information, Machine GUID, Product ID and Install Date values, as shown in Figure 5. Furthermore, it uses the same ID for generating the mutex Global\\&lt;32-byte ID&gt;.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_124430\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 5. Unique ID calculation.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nIt creates the registry key HKCU\\Software\\&lt;32-byte ID&gt; to store registry entries completed, RECOVERY BLOB and x25519_public to fingerprint its ransomware operations. Once the encryption process is completed, the registry entry completed is set with a value of 1. RECOVERY BLOB is a fingerprint identifier for the compromised organization, which is encrypted by the ChaCha20 encryption algorithm. The structure of the RECOVERY BLOB is shown in Table 1.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOffset\r\nData\r\nSize\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n0x00\r\nCurve25519 public key\r\n0x20\r\n\r\n\r\n0x20\r\nCryptographic random value\r\n0x0C\r\n\r\n\r\n0x2C\r\nCurve25519 secret key\r\n0x20\r\n\r\n\r\n0x4C\r\nUnique user ID\r\n0x10\r\n\r\n\r\n0x5C\r\nHardcoded RC4-decoded bytes\r\n0x10\r\n\r\n\r\n0x6C\r\nUnknown DWORD\r\n0x04\r\n\r\n\r\n0x70\r\nUnknown DWORD\r\n0x04\r\n\r\n\r\n0x74\r\nConstant value 0x1000\r\n0x04\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 1. Recovery blob structure.\r\nThe RECOVERY BLOB is then encrypted with ChaCha20 as shown in Figure 6 and stored in HKCU\\Software\\&lt;32-byte ID&gt;\\RECOVERY.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_124432\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 6. Recovery blob encryption.[\/caption]\r\nFile Encryption\r\nUnlike other ransomware, which normally contains a list of file extensions to identify eligible files for encryption, BlueSky consists of a list of extensions that are negated in the file encryption process. The file extensions used in BlueSky are listed below:\r\nldf, scr, icl, 386, cmd, ani, adv, theme, msi, rtp, diagcfg, msstyles, bin, hlp, shs, drv, wpx, bat, rom, msc, lnk, cab, spl, ps1, msu, ics, key, msp, com, sys, diagpkg, nls, diagcab, ico, lock, ocx, mpa, cur, cpl, mod, hta, exe, ini, icns, prf, dll, bluesky, nomedia, idx\r\n\r\nDirectory names excluded from encryption:\r\n$recycle.bin, $windows.~bt, $windows.~ws, boot, windows, windows.old, system volume information, perflogs, programdata, program files, program files (x86), all users, appdata, tor browser\r\n\r\nFilenames excluded from encryption:\r\n# decrypt files bluesky #.txt, # decrypt files bluesky #.html, ntuser.dat, iconcache.db, ntuser.dat.log, bootsect.bak, autorun.inf, bootmgr, ntldr, thumbs.db\r\n\r\nAs shown in Figure 7, BlueSky uses a multithreaded queue for encryption. It starts multiple threads \u2013 one responsible for file encryption, another for enumerating files on the local file system and mounted network shares to be added into the queue. This multithreaded architecture bears code similarities with Conti (Ransomware) v3. In particular, the network search module is an exact replica of Conti v3. However, there are certain differences in the file encryption routine. For instance, Conti v3 uses RSA- and AES-based file encryption, whereas BlueSky utilizes Curve25519- and ChaCha20-based file encryption.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_124434\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 7. Ransomware queues.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe file encryption of BlueSky is similar to Babuk Ransomware \u2013 both use Curve25519 to generate a public key for the host and generate a shared key with the public key of the attacker. After generating an elliptic curve key pair, BlueSky computes a hash of the shared key, and uses it to generate a file encryption key for the ChaCha20 algorithm. Finally, it reads the file buffer, encrypts it with ChaCha20 and replaces the contents of the original file, as shown in Figure 8.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_124437\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 8. File encryption routine.[\/caption]\r\nRedLine Infostealer Association\r\nAll samples we observed related to BlueSky ransomware were hosted at an active domain named kmsauto[.]us. When hunting for more samples related to BlueSky ransomware, we observed that several malware samples associated with the RedLine infostealer were hosted on the same domain. Although we did not find any code overlap between RedLine and BlueSky ransomware, similarities in the initial stages were observed, as both these families use a PowerShell downloader as the initial vector.\r\nConclusion\r\nRansomware authors are adopting modern advanced techniques such as encoding and encrypting malicious samples, or using multi-staged ransomware delivery and loading, to evade security defenses. BlueSky ransomware is capable of encrypting files on victim hosts at rapid speeds with multithreaded computation. In addition, the ransomware adopts obfuscation techniques, such as API hashing, to slow down the reverse engineering process for the analyst.\r\n\r\nIt is very likely that ransomware attacks will continue to grow with advanced encryption techniques and delivery mechanisms.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers with Cortex XDR, the Next-Generation Firewall and Advanced URL Filtering benefit from protections against the attacks discussed in this article. Additionally, the malicious indicators (domains, URLs and hashes) can be prevented with our DNS Security and WildFire services.\r\n\r\nIf you think you may have been impacted or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tEMEA: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAPAC: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n\r\nIf you have cyber insurance, you can request Unit 42 by name. You can also take preventative steps by requesting any of our cyber risk management services, such as our Ransomware Readiness Assessment.\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256 Hashes\r\nDescription\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n \t2280898cb29faf1785e782596d8029cb471537ec38352e5c17cc263f1f52b8ef\r\n \t3e035f2d7d30869ce53171ef5a0f761bfb9c14d94d9fe6da385e20b8d96dc2fb\r\n \t840af927adbfdeb7070e1cf73ed195cf48c8d5f35b6de12f58b73898d7056d3d\r\n \tb5b105751a2bf965a6b78eeff100fe4c75282ad6f37f98b9adcd15d8c64283ec\r\n \tc75748dc544629a8a5d08c0d8ba7fda3508a3efdaed905ad800ffddbc8d3b8df\r\n \te75717be1633b5e3602827dc3b5788ff691dd325b0eddd2d0d9ddcee29de364f\r\n\r\n\r\nBlueSky Ransomware Payloads\r\n\r\n\r\n08f491d46a9d05f1aebc83d724ca32c8063a2613250d50ce5b7e8ba469680605\r\nObfuscated PowerShell Downloader\r\n\r\n\r\n969a4a55bb5cabc96ff003467bd8468b3079f5c95c5823985416c019eb8abe2f\r\nPowerShell Downloader (decoded)\r\n\r\n\r\nc4e47cba1c5fedf9ba522bc2d2de54a482e0ac29c98358390af6dadc0a7d65ce\r\nCVE-2020-0796 SMBGhost Privilege Escalation Exploit\r\n\r\n\r\ncf64c08d97e6dfa5588c5fa016c25c4131ccc61b8deada7f9c8b2a41d8f5a32c\r\nJuicyPotato\r\n\r\n\r\n6c94a1bc67af21cedb0bffac03019dbf870649a182e58cc5960969adf4fbdd48\r\nCVE-2021-1732 Privilege Escalation Exploit\r\n\r\n\r\nRedLine\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n \t58db85f0c86640b4c3a2584e9ef5696c526190faf87eaa19085737685bc9e7f5\r\n \t9ca0e858ff6f163a128fb699d2b801b6b13a2eb1d6cd995302effa5f587cd8d8\r\n \taecfc82fa44790e0533f0bece0a1ab0860b163838646aa0c019187a37326d477\r\n \tbe3e665d389e8b85ceda1e2fc80a41a247de27d1d0b13ee0c2574c1e36ebc6d4\r\n\r\n\r\nPowerShell Downloader\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n \t4d696c106f568b99308565172116933c0e26ce2e9ace003a110e8bde0216ddab\r\n \taa7ff8badcffdff66df6d30bde51b6e3c960be0a3719b73d3875af8e1173bd94\r\n\r\n\r\nMSIL Downloader\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n \t0dfe7a93ff40834c072c7fdd9381771b1086b67f545fa83c766b2d67a911e47b\r\n \t1a30e0d65a8a09abc3feb1c86a0619845fc6ab9bdba3ae8800ecec55a647910e\r\n \t624f129189a05897c176e9feb519521c1b6ef528b0b52e1a7a3290e5a2313a6b\r\n \tfe2e5df2fae90fb90b56e4ea268e8ca68f46dc3365c22b840d865193a48be189\r\n\r\n\r\nPayloads\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nURLs\r\n\r\n \thxxps:\/\/kmsauto[.]us\/someone\/l.exe\r\n \thxxps:\/\/kmsauto[.]us\/app1.bin\r\n \thxxps:\/\/kmsauto[.]us\/server.txt\r\n \thxxps:\/\/kmsauto[.]us\/encoding.txt\r\n \thxxps:\/\/kmsauto[.]us\/all.txt\r\n \thxxps:\/\/kmsauto[.]us\/someone\/spooler.exe\r\n \thxxps:\/\/kmsauto[.]us\/sti\/sti.bin\r\n \thxxps:\/\/kmsauto[.]us\/someone\/potato.exe\r\n \thxxps:\/\/kmsauto[.]us\/someone\/ghost.exe\r\n \thxxps:\/\/kmsauto[.]us\/someone\/start.ps1\r\n\r\nRansom Note URLs\r\n\r\n \thttp:\/\/ccpyeuptrlatb2piua4ukhnhi7lrxgerrcrj4p2b5uhbzqm2xgdjaqid.onion\r\n\r\nRegistry Paths\r\n\r\n \tHKCU\\Software\\&lt;32-byte hex string&gt;\\completed\r\n \tHKCU\\Software\\&lt;32-byte hex string&gt;\\recoveryblob\r\n \tHKCU\\Software\\&lt;32-byte hex string&gt;\\x25519_public\r\n\r\nMITRE TTPs\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nID\r\nTechnique\r\nDescription\r\n\r\n\r\nT1486\r\nData Encrypted for Impact\r\nBlueSky can use CreateIoCompletionPort(), PostQueuedCompletionStatus() and GetQueuedCompletionPort() to rapidly encrypt files.\r\n\r\n\r\nT1140\r\nDeobfuscate\/Decode Files or Information\r\nBlueSky downloader base64-decodes and decompresses data to unpack the next stage payload.\r\n\r\n\r\nBlueSky ransomware payload encrypts ransom note with rc4-based encryption, and it uses a custom encryption scheme to encrypt embedded strings.\u00a0\r\n\r\n\r\nT1083\r\nFile and Directory Discovery\r\nBlueSky can discover files on a local system.\r\n\r\n\r\nT1106\r\nNative API\r\nBlueSky has used API calls during execution.\r\n\r\n\r\nT1135\r\nNetwork Share Discovery\r\nBlueSky can enumerate remote open SMB network shares using NetShareEnum().\r\n\r\n\r\nT1027\r\nObfuscated Files or Information\r\nBlueSky can use API obfuscation to protect its functionality from analysis.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAdditional Resources\r\n\r\n \tTracking the Operators of the Newly Emerged BlueSky Ransomware \u2013 by CloudSEK\r\n \tConti Ransomware Source Code \u2013 on GitHub @gharty03\r\n \tBabuk Ransomware v3 \u2013 by Chuong Dong\r\n \t2022 Unit 42 Ransomware Threat Report\r\n \t2022 Unit 42 Incident Response <script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

<!-- <script src="https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js"></script>  -->

<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</head>
<body class="post-template-default single single-post postid-124417 single-format-standard no-sidebar">
<header class="haeder py-15 position-relative z-index-2" style="display: none;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30 px-35">
    <div class="row">

                        <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/">
                <img src="/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/PANW_Parent.png" width="140px" alt="Logo" />
            </a>
        </div>
      <div class="col-sm-auto col-6 text-sm-center order-sm-2 order-4 second-logo-unit">
        <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/">
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/unit42-logo-white.svg" class="attachment-full size-full" alt="Unit42 Logo"  width="150" height="35"/>
        </a>

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-41" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-41"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/atoms/">ATOMs</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-119884" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-119884"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42">Security Consulting</a></li>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">
        </div>

<div class="cleanTopHtml htmlComp baseComponent parbase"><div class="base-component-spacer spacer-none  "></div>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

    <section class="section section--article">
        <div class="pa article-banner" style="background-image:url('https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/01_Ransomware_Category_1920x900.jpg')">
          <div class="l-container"> 
            <div class="l-breadcrumbs"> 
              <ul> <li> <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research Center</a></li><li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research</a></li><li class="is-current"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/ransomware/" role="link" title="Ransomware" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:hero:breadcrumb:Ransomware">Ransomware</a></li> </ul>

                  </ul>
                  
	<div class="ab__share" id="shareDropdown" role="button" aria-expanded="false">
	<a href="#" role="link" title="Click here to share" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:share" class="">Share<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/down-arrow.svg" alt="Down arrow"></a><ul class="share-dropdown" role="menu">

				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="mailto:?subject=BlueSky%20Ransomware:%20Fast%20Encryption%20via%20Multithreading&#038;body=Check%20out%20this%20article%20https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fbluesky-ransomware%2F" role="link" title="Share in email" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:share:email"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-sms.svg" alt="Link Email"></a>

    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/bluesky-ransomware/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-124417-_gcytq79ugzfy"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>BlueSky ransomware is an emerging family that has adopted modern techniques to evade security defenses.</p>
<p>Ransomware is a malicious program designed to encrypt a user’s data and demand a ransom for the decryption. BlueSky ransomware predominantly targets Windows hosts and utilizes multithreading to encrypt files on the host for faster encryption.</p>
<p>In our analysis, we found code fingerprints from samples of BlueSky ransomware that can be connected to the <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/conti-ransomware-gang/">Conti ransomware group</a>. In particular, the multithreaded architecture of BlueSky bears code similarities with Conti v3, and the network search module is an exact replica of it.</p>
<p>However, in another respect, BlueSky more closely resembles <a href="https://chuongdong.com/reverse%20engineering/2021/01/16/BabukRansomware-v3/">Babuk Ransomware</a>. Both use <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChaCha20-Poly1305">ChaCha20</a>, an algorithm for file encryption, along with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curve25519">Curve25519</a> for key generation.</p>
<p>According to research done by <a href="https://cloudsek.com/threatintelligence/tracking-the-operators-of-the-newly-emerged-bluesky-ransomware/">CloudSEK</a>, PowerShell scripting is used to drop and download BlueSky ransomware from a fake website to encrypt data. After successful encryption, BlueSky Ransomware renames the encrypted files with the file extension <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.bluesky</span> and drops a ransom note file named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"># DECRYPT FILES BLUESKY #.txt</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"># DECRYPT FILES BLUESKY #.html</span>.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers receive protections from BlueSky ransomware and other types of ransomware through <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr">Cortex XDR,</a> the <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall">Next-Generation Firewall</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/security-subscriptions">cloud-delivered security services</a> including <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall">WildFire</a>. The <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering">Advanced URL Filtering</a> subscription provides real-time URL analysis and malware prevention for BlueSky ransomware.</p>
<p>If you think you may have been impacted by a cyber incident, the <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42/respond/incident-response">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> is available 24/7/365. You can also take preventative steps by requesting any of our <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42/assess">cyber risk management services</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 56.0251%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 40.0955%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Related Unit 42 Topics</span></td>
<td style="width: 130.046%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/ransomware/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Ransomware</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/conti-ransomware/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Conti Ransomware</span></a></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-124417-_h9vr6a8h2vel"></a>Initial Dropper</h2>
<p>As shown in Figure 1, BlueSky ransomware is initially dropped by the PowerShell script <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">start.ps1</span>, which is hosted at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://kmsauto[.]us/someone/start.ps1</span>. The initial dropper is Base64-encoded and then DEFLATE-compressed, which is common behavior observed among PowerShell droppers.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124422" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124422" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124422 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/word-image-32.png" alt="The initial dropper for BlueSky ransomware, shown in the screenshot, is Base64-encoded and then DEFLATE-compressed, which is common behavior observed among PowerShell droppers. " width="900" height="393" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124422" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Initial dropper.</figcaption></figure>
<p>After extracting the embedded Base64-encoded stream from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">start.ps1</span>, the decoded and uncompressed data stream led to yet another PowerShell script called <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">stage.ps1</span>. This script contained countless irrelevant comments in an attempt to conceal malicious activity. After removing these excessive comments, we discovered that start.ps1 downloaded a number of payloads from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://kmsauto[.]us/someone/</span> based on the user’s privileges, as shown in Figure 2.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124424" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124424" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124424 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/word-image-33.png" alt="After removing irrelevant comments the malware authors had added in an attempt to conceal malicious activity, we discovered that start.ps1 downloaded a number of payloads based on the user's privileges, as shown in the code snippet here. " width="900" height="701" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124424" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Initial dropper (decoded).</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-124417-_z39i0zyt4tib"></a>Local Privilege Escalation</h2>
<p>Before downloading additional payloads to perform local privilege escalation, the PowerShell script, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">stage.ps1</span>, determines if it is being executed as a privileged user. If so, it moves to the next step and downloads and executes the ransomware payload. If not, it uses the following techniques to escalate local privileges, depending on the version of the host operating system. If the version of the host operating system is earlier than Windows 10, such as Windows 7, 8 or XP, then the script will download and execute a modified version of the local privilege escalation tool called <a href="https://github.com/ohpe/juicy-potato">JuicyPotato</a>. If the host is running Windows 10 or later, then the script will download and execute <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ghost.exe</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">spooler.exe</span> to exploit local privilege escalation vulnerabilities <a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/cve-2020-0796">CVE-2020-0796</a> and <a href="https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-1732">CVE-2021-1732</a> respectively.</p>
<h2><a id="post-124417-_1mccr1psnob0"></a>Ransomware Payload</h2>
<p>After gaining additional privileges, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">stage.ps1</span> downloads the final BlueSky ransomware payload from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://kmsauto[.]us/someone/l.exe</span> and saves it locally to the filesystem as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">javaw.exe</span>, attempting to masquerade as a legitimate Windows application. Eventually, the sample executes from the file path <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\javaw.exe</span>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-124417-_4m795485sl9l"></a>Ransom Note</h2>
<p>BlueSky drops the ransom note as a text file named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"># DECRYPT FILES BLUESKY #.txt</span> and an HTML file named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"># DECRYPT FILES BLUESKY #.html</span> in a local directory where it has encrypted files successfully and renamed them with the file extension <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.bluesky</span>. The content of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"># DECRYPT FILES BLUESKY #.html</span> is shown in Figure 3.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124426" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124426" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124426 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/word-image-9.jpeg" alt="Text of BlueSky ransom note: &quot;BlueSky: Your important files, documents, photos, videos, databases have been encrypted! The only way to decrypt and restore your files is with our private key and program. Any attempts to restore your files manually will damage your files. To restore your files follow these instructions: 1. Download and install Tor Browser. 2. Run Tor Browser. 3. In the Tor Browser open website [threat actor URL] 4. On the website enter your recovery ID [redacted] 5. Follow the instructions on the website. " width="900" height="434" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124426" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. BlueSky ransom note.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-124417-_kkllbv828k78"></a>Anti-Analysis Techniques</h2>
<p>BlueSky implements multiple anti-analysis techniques, including string encryption, API obfuscation and anti-debugging mechanisms, allowing it to obfuscate Windows API function names and use indirect calls for resolving APIs. Additionally, BlueSky encodes API names using DJB hashing functions as shown in Figure 4, hindering malware analysis.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124428" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124428" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124428 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/word-image-34.png" alt="BlueSky ransomware encodes API names using DJB hashing functions as shown, hindering malware analysis. " width="900" height="522" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124428" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. DJB hash matching.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-124417-_yv8g9pzc9n85"></a>Ransomware Artifacts</h2>
<p>BlueSky generates a unique user ID by computing the MD5 hash over the combined Volume Information, Machine GUID, Product ID and Install Date values, as shown in Figure 5. Furthermore, it uses the same ID for generating the mutex <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Global\&lt;32-byte ID&gt;</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124430" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124430" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124430 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/word-image-35.png" alt="BlueSky generates a unique user ID by computing the MD5 hash over the combined Volume Information, Machine GUID, Product ID and Install Date values, as shown. " width="900" height="777" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124430" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Unique ID calculation.</figcaption></figure>
<p>It creates the registry key <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">HKCU\Software\&lt;32-byte ID&gt;</span> to store registry entries completed, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RECOVERY BLOB</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">x25519_public</span> to fingerprint its ransomware operations. Once the encryption process is <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">completed</span>, the registry entry completed is set with a value of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1. RECOVERY BLOB</span> is a fingerprint identifier for the compromised organization, which is encrypted by the ChaCha20 encryption algorithm. The structure of the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RECOVERY BLOB</span> is shown in Table 1.</p>
<table style="width: 69.732%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<th style="width: 16.1194%;"><b>Offset</b></th>
<th style="width: 67.7612%;"><b>Data</b></th>
<th style="width: 168.498%;"><b>Size</b></th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 16.1194%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x00</span></td>
<td style="width: 67.7612%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Curve25519 public key</span></td>
<td style="width: 168.498%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x20</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 16.1194%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x20</span></td>
<td style="width: 67.7612%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Cryptographic random value</span></td>
<td style="width: 168.498%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x0C</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 16.1194%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x2C</span></td>
<td style="width: 67.7612%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Curve25519 secret key</span></td>
<td style="width: 168.498%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x20</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 16.1194%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x4C</span></td>
<td style="width: 67.7612%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Unique user ID</span></td>
<td style="width: 168.498%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x10</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 16.1194%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x5C</span></td>
<td style="width: 67.7612%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Hardcoded RC4-decoded bytes</span></td>
<td style="width: 168.498%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x10</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 16.1194%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x6C</span></td>
<td style="width: 67.7612%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Unknown </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">DWORD</span></td>
<td style="width: 168.498%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x04</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 16.1194%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x70</span></td>
<td style="width: 67.7612%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Unknown </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">DWORD</span></td>
<td style="width: 168.498%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x04</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 16.1194%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x74</span></td>
<td style="width: 67.7612%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Constant value </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x1000</span></td>
<td style="width: 168.498%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">0x04</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #999999; font-size: 10pt;"><em>Table 1. Recovery blob structure.</em></span></p>
<p>The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RECOVERY BLOB</span> is then encrypted with ChaCha20 as shown in Figure 6 and stored in <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">HKCU\Software\&lt;32-byte ID&gt;\RECOVERY</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124432" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124432" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124432 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/word-image-36.png" alt="The RECOVERY BLOB is encrypted with ChaCha20 as shown and stored in HKCU\Software\&lt;32-byte ID &gt;\RECOVERY" width="900" height="307" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124432" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Recovery blob encryption.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-124417-_xov87zn4upcn"></a>File Encryption</h2>
<p>Unlike other ransomware, which normally contains a list of file extensions to identify eligible files for encryption, BlueSky consists of a list of extensions that are negated in the file encryption process. The file extensions used in BlueSky are listed below:<br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ldf, scr, icl, 386, cmd, ani, adv, theme, msi, rtp, diagcfg, msstyles, bin, hlp, shs, drv, wpx, bat, rom, msc, lnk, cab, spl, ps1, msu, ics, key, msp, com, sys, diagpkg, nls, diagcab, ico, lock, ocx, mpa, cur, cpl, mod, hta, exe, ini, icns, prf, dll, bluesky, nomedia, idx</span></p>
<p>Directory names excluded from encryption:<br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">$recycle.bin, $windows.~bt, $windows.~ws, boot, windows, windows.old, system volume information, perflogs, programdata, program files, program files (x86), all users, appdata, tor browser</span></p>
<p>Filenames excluded from encryption:<br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"># decrypt files bluesky #.txt, # decrypt files bluesky #.html, ntuser.dat, iconcache.db, ntuser.dat.log, bootsect.bak, autorun.inf, bootmgr, ntldr, thumbs.db</span></p>
<p>As shown in Figure 7, BlueSky uses a multithreaded queue for encryption. It starts multiple threads – one responsible for file encryption, another for enumerating files on the local file system and mounted network shares to be added into the queue. This multithreaded architecture bears code similarities with Conti (Ransomware) v3. In particular, the network search module is an exact replica of Conti v3. However, there are certain differences in the file encryption routine. For instance, Conti v3 uses RSA- and AES-based file encryption, whereas BlueSky utilizes Curve25519- and ChaCha20-based file encryption.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124434" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124434" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124434 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/word-image-37.png" alt="The figure shows how BlueSky ransomware uses a multithreaded queue for encryption. This multithreaded architecture bears code similarities with Conti v3. " width="900" height="185" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124434" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Ransomware queues.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The file encryption of BlueSky is similar to <a href="https://chuongdong.com/reverse%20engineering/2021/01/16/BabukRansomware-v3/">Babuk Ransomware</a> – both use Curve25519 to generate a public key for the host and generate a shared key with the public key of the attacker. After generating an elliptic curve key pair, BlueSky computes a hash of the shared key, and uses it to generate a file encryption key for the ChaCha20 algorithm. Finally, it reads the file buffer, encrypts it with ChaCha20 and replaces the contents of the original file, as shown in Figure 8.</p>
<figure id="attachment_124437" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-124437" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img  class="wp-image-124437 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/Figure8BlueSky.png" alt="BlueSky ransomware generates the keypair, initializes key for ChaCha20, reads file content for encryption, encrypts the file and replaces the contents of the original file. Comments in green highlight the steps of the process. " width="900" height="672" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-124437" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. File encryption routine.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-124417-_n0ob4pvl6v6"></a>RedLine Infostealer Association</h2>
<p>All samples we observed related to BlueSky ransomware were hosted at an active domain named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kmsauto[.]us</span>. When hunting for more samples related to BlueSky ransomware, we observed that several malware samples associated with the RedLine infostealer were hosted on the same domain. Although we did not find any code overlap between RedLine and BlueSky ransomware, similarities in the initial stages were observed, as both these families use a PowerShell downloader as the initial vector.</p>
<h2><a id="post-124417-_2ppj4li8j1wa"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>Ransomware authors are adopting modern advanced techniques such as encoding and encrypting malicious samples, or using multi-staged ransomware delivery and loading, to evade security defenses. BlueSky ransomware is capable of encrypting files on victim hosts at rapid speeds with multithreaded computation. In addition, the ransomware adopts obfuscation techniques, such as API hashing, to slow down the reverse engineering process for the analyst.</p>
<p>It is very likely that ransomware attacks will continue to grow with advanced encryption techniques and delivery mechanisms.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers with <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr">Cortex XDR</a>, the <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall">Next-Generation Firewall</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering">Advanced URL Filtering</a> benefit from protections against the attacks discussed in this article. Additionally, the malicious indicators (domains, URLs and hashes) can be prevented with our <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/threat-detection-and-prevention/dns-security">DNS Security</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/wildfire">WildFire</a> services.</p>
<p>If you think you may have been impacted or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the<a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html"> Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>EMEA: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>APAC: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
</ul>
<p>If you have cyber insurance, you can request Unit 42 by name. You can also take preventative steps by requesting any of our <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42/assess">cyber risk management services</a>, such as our <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42/assess/ransomware-readiness-assessment">Ransomware Readiness Assessment</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-124417-_44mv3hh9vd0m"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>
<table style="width: 100.06700000000001%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 75.08216986399427%;"><b>SHA256 Hashes</b></td>
<td style="width: 63.05893013600572%;"><b>Description</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 75.08216986399427%;">
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2280898cb29faf1785e782596d8029cb471537ec38352e5c17cc263f1f52b8ef</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">3e035f2d7d30869ce53171ef5a0f761bfb9c14d94d9fe6da385e20b8d96dc2fb</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">840af927adbfdeb7070e1cf73ed195cf48c8d5f35b6de12f58b73898d7056d3d</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b5b105751a2bf965a6b78eeff100fe4c75282ad6f37f98b9adcd15d8c64283ec</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c75748dc544629a8a5d08c0d8ba7fda3508a3efdaed905ad800ffddbc8d3b8df</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">e75717be1633b5e3602827dc3b5788ff691dd325b0eddd2d0d9ddcee29de364f</span></li>
</ul>
</td>
<td style="width: 63.05893013600572%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">BlueSky Ransomware Payloads</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 75.08216986399427%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">08f491d46a9d05f1aebc83d724ca32c8063a2613250d50ce5b7e8ba469680605</span></td>

</tbody>
</table>
<p>URLs</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://kmsauto[.]us/someone/l.exe</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://kmsauto[.]us/app1.bin</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://kmsauto[.]us/server.txt</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://kmsauto[.]us/encoding.txt</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://kmsauto[.]us/all.txt</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://kmsauto[.]us/someone/spooler.exe</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://kmsauto[.]us/sti/sti.bin</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://kmsauto[.]us/someone/potato.exe</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://kmsauto[.]us/someone/ghost.exe</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://kmsauto[.]us/someone/start.ps1</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Ransom Note URLs</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">http://ccpyeuptrlatb2piua4ukhnhi7lrxgerrcrj4p2b5uhbzqm2xgdjaqid.onion</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Registry Paths</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">HKCU\Software\&lt;32-byte hex string&gt;\completed</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">HKCU\Software\&lt;32-byte hex string&gt;\recoveryblob</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">HKCU\Software\&lt;32-byte hex string&gt;\x25519_public</span></li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-124417-_akwvt7tf6krj"></a>MITRE TTPs</h2>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 9.388469226361032%;"><b>ID</b></td>
<td style="width: 22.22447077363897%;"><b>Technique</b></td>
<td style="width: 67.6703%;"><b>Description</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 9.388469226361032%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1486"><span style="font-weight: 400;">T1486</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 22.22447077363897%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1486"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Data Encrypted for Impact</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 67.6703%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">BlueSky can use</span> <span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CreateIoCompletionPort(), PostQueuedCompletionStatus()</span> </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">and</span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"> GetQueuedCompletionPort()</span> <span style="font-weight: 400;">to rapidly encrypt files.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 9.388469226361032%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1140"><span style="font-weight: 400;">T1140</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 22.22447077363897%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1140"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 67.6703%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">BlueSky downloader base64-decodes and decompresses data to unpack the next stage payload.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;"><br />
</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">BlueSky ransomware payload encrypts ransom note with rc4-based encryption, and it uses a custom encryption scheme to encrypt embedded strings.</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> </span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 9.388469226361032%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1083"><span style="font-weight: 400;">T1083</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 22.22447077363897%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1083"><span style="font-weight: 400;">File and Directory Discovery</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 67.6703%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">BlueSky can discover files on a local system.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 9.388469226361032%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106"><span style="font-weight: 400;">T1106</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 22.22447077363897%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Native API</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 67.6703%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">BlueSky has used API calls during execution.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 9.388469226361032%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1135"><span style="font-weight: 400;">T1135</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 22.22447077363897%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1135"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Network Share Discovery</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 67.6703%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">BlueSky can enumerate remote open SMB network shares usi</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">ng </span><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">NetShareEnum()</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 9.388469226361032%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027"><span style="font-weight: 400;">T1027</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 22.22447077363897%;"><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Obfuscated Files or Information</span></a></td>
<td style="width: 67.6703%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">BlueSky can use API obfuscation to protect its functionality from analysis.</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>

    <div class="l-container">
            <h2>Related Ransomware Resources</h2>
      <div class="blog-slider" id="blogSlider"> 
                    <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/09_Cybercrime_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="A pictorial representation of Akira ransomware, distributed by Howling Scorpius.                             </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/top-cyberthreats/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:related-resources:Threat Assessment: Howling Scorpius (Akira Ransomware):High Profile Threats"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/top-threats.svg" alt=" category icon">High Profile Threats</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-12-02T23:00:10+00:00">December 2, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-assessment-howling-scorpius-akira-ransomware/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:related-resources:Threat Assessment: Howling Scorpius (Akira Ransomware)">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Threat Assessment: Howling Scorpius (Akira Ransomware)</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/howling-scorpius/" title="Howling Scorpius" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:related-resources:Threat Assessment: Howling Scorpius (Akira Ransomware):Howling Scorpius">Howling Scorpius</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/leak-site/" title="Leak site" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:related-resources:Threat Assessment: Howling Scorpius (Akira Ransomware):Leak site">Leak site</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/torrenting/" title="torrenting" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:related-resources:Threat Assessment: Howling Scorpius (Akira Ransomware):torrenting">Torrenting</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/threat-assessment-howling-scorpius-akira-ransomware/" title="Threat Assessment: Howling Scorpius (Akira Ransomware)" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:related-resources:Threat Assessment: Howling Scorpius (Akira Ransomware):read now">

              </div>

				<li role="listitem">

                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/03_Ransomware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of ransomware activity in the first half of 2024.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/trend-reports/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:related-resources:Ransomware Review: First Half of 2024:Trend Reports"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-report-white-1.svg" alt=" category icon">Trend Reports</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-08-09T10:00:03+00:00">August 9, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit-42-ransomware-leak-site-data-analysis/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:related-resources:Ransomware Review: First Half of 2024">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Ransomware Review: First Half of 2024</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/healthcare/" title="Healthcare" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:related-resources:Ransomware Review: First Half of 2024:Healthcare">Healthcare</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/lockbit/" title="LockBit" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:related-resources:Ransomware Review: First Half of 2024:LockBit">LockBit</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/ransomhub/" title="RansomHub" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:related-resources:Ransomware Review: First Half of 2024:RansomHub">RansomHub</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/unit-42-ransomware-leak-site-data-analysis/" title="Ransomware Review: First Half of 2024" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:related-resources:Ransomware Review: First Half of 2024:read now">
                    Read now                    <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-right-arrow-withtail.svg" alt="Right arrow">
                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="718" height="440" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/05_Ransomware_Category_1505x922-718x440.jpg" class="lozad" alt="A pictorial representation of RA World ransomware group. A digital graphic of a U.S. dollar bill disintegrating into pixels, symbolizing digital transformation or the concept of cryptocurrency against a backdrop of a dark, tech-inspired visual theme." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/05_Ransomware_Category_1505x922-718x440.jpg 718w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/05_Ransomware_Category_1505x922-1143x700.jpg 1143w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/05_Ransomware_Category_1505x922-768x470.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/05_Ransomware_Category_1505x922.jpg 1505w" sizes="(max-width: 718px) 100vw, 718px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:related-resources:From RA Group to RA World: Evolution of a Ransomware Group:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-07-22T10:00:51+00:00">July 22, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/ra-world-ransomware-group-updates-tool-set/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:related-resources:From RA Group to RA World: Evolution of a Ransomware Group">
                    <h4 class="post-title">From RA Group to RA World: Evolution of a Ransomware Group</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/extortion/" title="Extortion" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:related-resources:From RA Group to RA World: Evolution of a Ransomware Group:Extortion">Extortion</a>

                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Generic-B-1920x900-1-786x368.png" class="lozad" alt="Constellation image representing the constellation schema used by Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 to track nation-state and cybercrime threat actor groups" decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Generic-B-1920x900-1-786x368.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Generic-B-1920x900-1-1493x700.png 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Generic-B-1920x900-1-768x360.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Generic-B-1920x900-1-1536x720.png 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Generic-B-1920x900-1.png 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure>

              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="bluesky-ransomware:related-resources:Threat Actor Groups Tracked by Palo Alto Networks Unit 42:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-06-28T01:00:15+00:00">June 27, 2024</time></span>
